awd_titl_txt: Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Course:  Frontiers and Techniques in Plant Science
awd_abstract_narration:
The Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory course on Frontiers and Techniques in Plant Science provides opportunities for a diverse group of scientists to learn about the latest developments and methods that are used for plant science research. The three-week course offers intensive immersion into the cross-disciplinary, cutting-edge approaches being used in plant biology research at the interface of biological and computational sciences. Students who take the course will be prepared to join the next generation of leaders in interdisciplinary research on plants.

Scientific content of the course evolves in parallel to trends in the field; current emphasis is on genomic, evolutionary, analytical and computational themes using a number of plant models, including Arabidopsis, maize and tomato. The course format includes lectures, hands-on laboratories, and informal discussions catalyzed by three instructors and a cadre of invited lecturers who are leaders in their fields of research. Faced with high demand for the course, course organizers pay special attention to enrolling a demographically diverse group of students. Post-course evaluations by both instructors and students helps to inform decision-making about content for subsequent years. Past participants have reported high satisfaction with the course, and long-term follow-up indicates that the course has long-lasting impact on the careers and research directions of participants.

FRONTIERS AND TECHNIQUES IN PLANT SCIENCE

Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory

June 29 - July 19, 2018

INSTRUCTORS:

Sean Cutler, University of California Riverside, Riverside, CA

Jose Dinneny, Stanford University, Stanford, CA

Uta Paszkowski, University of Cambridge, Cambridge, United Kingdom

The Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory summer course on Frontiers and Techniques in Plant Science (FTPS) has been continuously taught with funding by the National Science Foundation since its inception 30 years ago. Topics cover a wide variety of plant systems, reflecting current research priorities in many US and international laboratories and the expansion of genome-enabled plant species and technologies. The course allows students to take advantage of a wealth of technological resources applied to biological processes that are unique to plants. It is designed to fulfill a continuing demand within the plant science community for training in molecular and genetic approaches. The intention is to (1) teach state of the art techniques to scientists already involved in plant research so that they can apply these technologies to their own future research and (2) introduce scientists familiar with microbial, animal or plant systems to cutting-edge research carried out by top plant biologists.

The course consisted of a rigorous lecture series, a hands-on laboratory, and informal workshops on a variety of research tools. Speakers provided both an overview of a broad area of expertise and an in-depth discussion of their work. These speakers were experts in a variety of plant species, research questions and applications, and brought a range of technical expertise to the course. The laboratory sessions provided intensive training in modern techniques in plant biology and reinforced the lessons learned in lectures. The lecture topics ranged from plant anatomy to phylogenetics, aspects of morphogenesis and development, plant-environment interactions, hormone signaling, metabolism, cell wall structure, and plants in the context of ?bioenergy?. The experimental approaches that corresponded to these topics include microscopy to examine gene expression, transformation techniques, isolation of actively translated transcripts through ribosome purification followed by quantitative PCR, biochemical fractionation of proteins, proteomics, and metabolite profiling. In recognition of the increasing importance of computational methods in plant biology, we also included modules on phylogenetics, QTL mapping, machine vision, and the use of statistical methods for global analysis of transcript, protein, and metabolite levels.

 This course was supported with funds provided by: the National Science Foundation
